description.summary: Monstrous wolf from Norse mythology, son of Loki, destined to kill Odin at Ragnarök. Bound by the gods with the magical ribbon Gleipnir after growing too dangerous.
description.full: Fenrir (also called Fenrisúlfr) is a gigantic and monstrous wolf in Norse mythology, son of the trickster god Loki and the jötunn Angrboða. Brother to Jörmungandr (the World Serpent) and Hel (goddess of the underworld), Fenrir grew so large and dangerous that the gods decided he must be bound. After breaking two chains, Fenrir was finally restrained by Gleipnir, a magical ribbon made from impossible things. The binding cost the god Týr his right hand when Fenrir bit it off, realizing he'd been tricked. Prophecy states that at Ragnarök (the end of the world), Fenrir will break free, kill Odin the Allfather, and be slain in turn by Víðarr, Odin's son. Fenrir represents inevitable doom, the consequences of fear and broken trust, and chaos that cannot be permanently contained. His myth is central to the Norse understanding of fate, the limits of divine power, and the cyclical nature of destruction and renewal.

major_myths.title: Raising of Fenrir
major_myths.description: The Æsir brought young Fenrir to Asgard to watch over him. Only Týr was brave enough to feed him, but Fenrir grew alarmingly large and dangerous.

major_myths.title: The Binding Attempts
major_myths.description: The gods forged chains Læðingr and Dromi to bind Fenrir. He broke both easily, growing more suspicious of the gods' intentions.

major_myths.title: Gleipnir and Týr's Sacrifice
major_myths.description: The dwarves crafted Gleipnir from six impossible things: cat's footfall, woman's beard, mountain roots, bear's sinews, fish's breath, and bird's spittle. Fenrir agreed to be bound only if a god placed their hand in his mouth as pledge. Týr volunteered, and when Fenrir couldn't break free, he bit off Týr's hand.

major_myths.title: Ragnarök Prophecy
major_myths.description: At Ragnarök, Fenrir will break free. His jaws will stretch from earth to sky. He will swallow Odin, killing the Allfather. Víðarr will then kill Fenrir, avenging his father.
